Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ADAD0600 - Transmedia Storytelling Studio","description":"

Transmedia storytelling is the practice of designing, sharing, and participating in a cohesive story experience across multiple traditional and digital delivery platforms - for entertainment, advertising and marketing, or social change.


Have you ever read a book, seen a movie, watched a television show, or played a game that centred around different aspects of a larger story or universe? You may be familiar with popular examples of such universes like Star Wars, Marvel, and The Walking Dead (to name a few). How do the professionals develop such expansive narratives? How do they ensure that each element stays true to the original story? How do they innovatively use different technologies to share the stories, grow audiences and create an active and involved community of fans?


This intensive face-to-face studio is an extension of the 'Transmedia Storytelling: Narrative worlds, emerging technologies, and global audiences' Coursera Massive Open Online Course (MOOC), and is only open to students who have previously passed this course. Students may enrol in the MOOC for free at any time prior to undertaking this course http://bit.ly/2cOy1hq.


In this studio, you will refine your strategy for developing and telling your own transmedia story that you began to develop in the MOOC. You will learn how to shape your ideas into compelling and well structured narratives and complex storyworlds; identify, understand, and engage different audiences in your stories; create cohesive user experiences across different platforms; and evaluate existing and emerging technologies to share your story with the world, and help your audience participate in the larger storyworld you create. The course culminates you prototyping and testing the transmedia storytelling experiences that you have designed.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"feec707bdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619d7","name":""},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Audience experience map","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"50","description":"

NOTE: Students will have completed a structured series of assessments in the MOOC that will produce an overarching transmedia storytelling strategy that they bring to the face-to-face on campus studios. The assessment described in this document is that of the face-to-face component. A summary of the MOOC assessment is attached to this proposal.

Students will review their original transmedia storytelling strategy developed within the MOOC. This comprises an outline of the story to be told, key themes and characters, an analysis of the audience, a description of the moths and key identifiers of the transmedia experience, and an exploration of the types of technologies that could be used to tell different elements of the story.

More detail will be added to each of these aspects of their strategy, enabling them to use this information to develop a detailed audience journey map, which maps in detail how the story will be told across different technological platforms, and defines how the experiences will be designed to provide a cohesive additive story experience for audiences.

Students will nominate to elements or experiences within their story world which they will design in detail in the following assignment.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"72ec707bdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619cf","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"beec707bdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619d1","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"eeec707bdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619a6","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"2aec707bdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96199d","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Prototyping transmedia experiences","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"50","description":"

Students will reflect upon feedback from peers and the lecturer about their audience journey map, refining where necessary. They will nominate to elements or experiences within their map which they will design in detail to prototype level. Students will be expected to produce prototypes of these experiences on different technological platforms that their classmates will evaluate. Students must demonstrate a cohesiveness of story experience across platforms, show how they have anticipated and designed for audience requirements, and how they have applied the affordances of the technologies chosen to best effect.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Paddington","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"ADAD0901","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ADAD0901 - Graphics and Contemporary Society","description":"

The graphic image has emerged as a prevailing form of communication in everyday life as a result of the shift from textual models, which represented the lingua franca for discourses in the arts, culture and media, to one of visual experience. This 'pictorial turn' has been spearheaded by the emergence of new digital technologies available to the masses in the creation, display and rapid transmission of the image to wider audiences via the Internet, film, photography, print and video.


The course introduces topical issues in contemporary graphic design and its significance in society, including communicating identities, designing for national and global audiences, graphics as strategic communication between the client and the public, and design as social policy. As a social activity, the graphic communication of image and text engages critical reflection in the production and consumption of cultural knowledge, particularly the process of meaning making in national iconography, product advertising and editorial design.


This fully online course comprises a series of integrated lectures, learning activities and assessment tasks that inform your ability to analyse and interpret the graphics in the world around you. You will apply this knowledge in the creation of a series your own graphic design responses to progressively challenging briefs that enable you to explore the relationship between image and cultural interpretation and identity. You will have the chance to discuss ideas and graphic design solutions with your peers and lecturer, encouraging critical reflection, group interaction and collaborative development of ideas and projects.

The graphic image has emerged as a prevailing form of communication in everyday life as a result of the shift from textual models, which represented the lingua franca for discourses in the arts, culture and media, to one of visual experience. This 'pictorial turn' has been spearheaded by the emergence of new digital technologies available to the masses in the creation, display and rapid transmission of the image to wider audiences via the Internet, film, photography, print and video.

The course introduces topical issues in contemporary graphic design and its significance in society, including communicating identities, designing for national and global audiences, graphics as strategic communication between the client and the public, and design as social policy. As a social activity, the graphic communication of image and text engages critical reflection in the production and consumption of cultural knowledge, particularly the process of meaning making in national iconography, product advertising and editorial design.

This fully online course comprises a series of integrated lectures, learning activities and assessment tasks that inform your ability to analyse and interpret the graphics in the world around you. You will apply this knowledge in the creation of a series your own graphic design responses to progressively challenging briefs that enable you to explore the relationship between image and cultural interpretation and identity. You will have the chance to discuss ideas and graphic design solutions with your peers and lecturer, encouraging critical reflection, group interaction and collaborative development of ideas and projects.

1","description":"

This course introduces you to studio practice in contemporary Art, Media and Design. One of two Gateway studios, the course underpins your future development as a studio practitioner by allowing you to conceptualise and situate your practice through a series of seminars, workshops and projects designed to challenge ideas around practice and creativity.


Major themes addressed include: perception and its transformation, the roles of time, change and materiality, and how scoring and encoding strategies are embedded in contemporary studio practice.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"f50ebcfbdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619c7","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 3: Curated experiments","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"40","description":"

For this assessment students undertake focused experimentation that leads to the development of three artworks/designed objects. The theme students will explore for this assessment will be the weekly theme that the group investigated for Assessment 2. This assessment consists of 3 artworks/designed objects and a 300 word statement.


Written Feedback

A group presentation (PechaKucha) in which students present their findings (experiments, research, speculation) around a creative problem. This assessment consists of a presentation, a one-page summary of the presentation and a bibliography of materials referenced.


Written feedback.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"6d0ebcfbdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619ae","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"f90ebcfbdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619c3","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"950ebcfbdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961983","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 1: Transformations","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

Through a process of experimentation students transform and everyday object (eg. a box) into an artwork/designed object.  This assessment consists of 3 experiments, 1 artwork/designed object and a 200-word statement describing the transformation process.


Written feedback

contentlets.description:
This course introduces you to studio practice in contemporary Art, Media and Design. One of two Gateway studios, the course underpins your future development as a studio practitioner by allowing you to conceptualise and situate your practice through a series of seminars, workshops and projects designed to challenge ideas around practice and creativity.

Major themes addressed include: perception and its transformation, the roles of time, change and materiality, and how scoring and encoding strategies are embedded in contemporary studio practice.
contentlets.title: Studio Gateway 1

2","description":"

Studio Gateway 2 introduces you to studio practice in contemporary Art, Media and Design. The course underpins your ongoing development as a studio practitioner by allowing you to conceptualise and situate your practice through a series of seminars, workshops and projects designed to challenge ideas around practice and creativity. The course will enable you to work collaboratively and independently, using self and peer evaluation and reflection, and to demonstrate an understanding of, and an ability to use, conceptual and experimental creativity and idea generation. Major themes addressed include: contexts and spaces; transformation and experimentation; and identity.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"c50ebcfbdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96193c","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 1: Poster","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

The purpose of this assessment is to produce preliminary work towards Assessment 2. In Week 2, students will choose one research question (provided in course outline). In Week 4, you will submit an A2 poster and a 300 word statement posted on Tumblr. This assessment will be a product of the student's  initial research and experimentation around your chosen question.


Written Feedback

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"050ebcfbdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961930","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"410ebcfbdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961933","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"340ebcfbdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961911","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 2: Research Project","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"45","description":"

In this assessment, students will develop a project based on your chosen research question. During class students will engage with a number of creative processes related to the weekly themes and each week you will devise an experiment that engages with that week’s theme. These experiments will be used to develop and shape the students' final project. The final project will be a work or body of works (in any form or media) plus a 700-word concept statement and bibliography.


Written Feedback

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"050ebcfbdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961930","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"8d0ebcfbdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961935","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"c90ebcfbdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961938","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"7c0ebcfbdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961915","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 3: Collective Publication","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"35","description":"

This assessment is a group assessment. Each group will produce a 12-page PDF publication. The publication will explore a theme which will change each year to reflect a research strength at UNSW Art & Design (or to correspond to a conference, exhibition, etc. at the Faculty). This project is not a 'report' but a conceptual and experimental engagement with creative practice into an emerging contemporary theme.


Written Freedback

course."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ADAD1100 - Communication in Art, Design and Media","description":"

Are you a good Art, Design and Media communicator?


Communication underpins the success of Art, Design and Media practice. This course boosts your skills and confidence in visual arts communication across multi-format art, design and media dialogue and debate. It develops your professional reading and academic writing, discussion and presentation abilities, enabling you to interpret different arts related texts in both traditional and digital formats. You will engage in individual, group and online communication activities. This will enhance your ability to discuss creative practices in preparation for working as art, design and media practitioners, arts educators, historians, administrators or cultural commentators. It will also assist with further studies in future.


By unpacking different communication styles, contexts and influences in class you will learn to identify and use English language forms, features, structures and referencing protocols. This will improve your capacity for critique, research and writing of exhibition and media reviews, artist statements, catalogue essays, academic papers and presentations. The course will also provide professional insight into how good communication is used in the arts. Keeping an online reflective journal will help you to monitor personal progress and take full advantage of regular tutor and peer feedback.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"935fb4ffdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961943","name":""},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Peer Presentation - Due Weeks 11 - 12","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":"Task 3: Peer Presentation This is a composite task. It involves preparation and delivery of a 5 minute academic poster presentation to the class, which communicates visual, verbal and written information about your personal creative interests or practices including: - An engaging and coherent delivery of visual, verbal and written content - Speaker-led group discussion based on two questions, and - One page hard copy handout of key messages for future reference. This task requires you to synthesise visual,verbal and written information into a professionally coherent poster presentation. You may speak in response to either mounted material, or PowerPoint screen, or animation segment, or Internet page, or some other relevant visual presentation format. The challenge is for you to engage your audience, communicate your message and manage the presentation delivery within the timeframe. The aim is to succinctly showcase the meaning and ideas behind your creative works and practices, concluding with a brief group discussion. You will need to be organised, speak clearly and present yourself in a confident, honest and professionally relaxed manner.
This task is peer assessed and teacher moderated, with feedback provided during the live presentations. In addition to delivering your own presentation you are also required to attend presentations made by your classmates and evaluate each one against the following assessment criteria: 1. Interesting academic poster with well paced presentation that engaged audience 2. Synthesis of visual, verbal and written information successfully presented in timeframe 3. Confident command and delivery of information in chosen format 4. Relaxed personal style in leading group discussion with professional handout provided.","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"435fb4ffdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96193d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"9f5fb4ffdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96193f","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"325fb4ffdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96191d","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Extended Academic Writing: 1,500 word essay - Due Week 7","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"40","description":"Task 2: 1,500 word essay - Due Week 7 In accordance with in-class guidance you are required to independently: - Select from a short list of different types of academic writing including a) Critique of an exhibition, design product or digital media initiative, or b) journal article or catalogue essay presenting a coherent argument, or c) Artist statement describing cultural precedent and asserting critical relevance of a specific creative project - Use the library to research ideas, quotes and visuals, noting potential references - Plan, structure and draft an outline of the paper, which includes at least one visual and one textual reference (ready for consultation weeks 4 - 6) - compose and write a well reasoned, presented and referenced academic essay.
Initial teacher feedback is provided on draft essay to individual students in practical workshops during weeks 4 - 6. Written feedback will accompany return of final essay submissions marked against the following assessment criteria: 1. Purposeful use of library to source ideas and identify quotes and visual references 2. Productive plan and structure for draft paper and responsiveness to feedback 3. Appropriate use of academic English and referencing of visual, textual and other sources within 1,500 word limit 4. Engaging, coherent and well reasoned treatment of narrative or critical content. Online feedback for essays submitted Week 7 that are considered to be below minimum academic standard, teachers may recommend to selected students that they resubmit their essay in Week 9 for "Pass / Fail" result.","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"035fb4ffdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96192b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"4f5fb4ffdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96192d","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"4b5fb4ffdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961921","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Short Interpretive Writing: 500 words - Due Week 3","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"Task 1: 500 word interpretive writing - Due Week 3 (submitted online) In response to a shared reading you are required to: - Collaborate in pairs (or small groups) to identify key issues in the set text - Discuss and take notes on the origin, influences and implications of these ideas - Answer three contextual questions, "Who" is the intended audience?, "What" is the reading about? and "Why" is it relevant to studying Art, Design and/or Media? - Use your notes and answers to individually write your own interpretation of the reading in 500 words using plain English to discuss the source of this reference and provide a brief summary of its meaning, importance or possible usefulness in future.
Initial feedback from peers will be shared during the preparative activities for this task. Written feedback from teacher will be provided online in response to student submissions marked against the following assessment criteria: 1. Engagement with reading, preparatory investigation and contextual questions 2. Meaningful analysis and interpretation of text within 500 words 3. Appropriate use of plain English sentences, grammar, spelling and punctuation 4. Appropriate acknowledgement of source.","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"035fb4ffdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96192b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"4f5fb4ffdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96192d","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"f65fb4ffdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961918","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/ADAD1100.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}
contentlets.keywords: art and design,academic literacies,making presentations,communication skills,visual arts research and writing
contentlets.description:
Are you a good Art, Design and Media communicator?

Communication underpins the success of Art, Design and Media practice. This course boosts your skills and confidence in visual arts communication across multi-format art, design and media dialogue and debate. It develops your professional reading and academic writing, discussion and presentation abilities, enabling you to interpret different arts related texts in both traditional and digital formats. You will engage in individual, group and online communication activities. This will enhance your ability to discuss creative practices in preparation for working as art, design and media practitioners, arts educators, historians, administrators or cultural commentators. It will also assist with further studies in future.

By unpacking different communication styles, contexts and influences in class you will learn to identify and use English language forms, features, structures and referencing protocols. This will improve your capacity for critique, research and writing of exhibition and media reviews, artist statements, catalogue essays, academic papers and presentations. The course will also provide professional insight into how good communication is used in the arts. Keeping an online reflective journal will help you to monitor personal progress and take full advantage of regular tutor and peer feedback.
contentlets.title: Communication in Art, Design and Media

Systems for Interactive Media","description":"

In this course students will be introduced to algorithms and the basics of programming interactive systems for artists and designers. Students will learn to work with leading development tools for programming interactive media experiences and will learn core principles of computer programming, software design patterns and data structures. They will learn about the core paradigms for creative programming, including code-based and visual programming environments. The course will cover the basics of designing interactive systems, dealing with graphics, sound, text, files and file systems, common data types such as numbers and colours, designing motion and introducing randomness into programs. These concepts will be applied to the creation of interactive installations and artworks, and students will make a prototype system. This course provides a series of reusable learning resources that students can refer back to in subsequent courses.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"3bfc347bdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619ba","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Inventing an Interference System","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

Invent a blueprint for a conceptual system that employs some of the developed tactics in the previous assignment. You may use whatever media you feel would express the concept best. Invite your peers to evaluate and interfere with your interference system, so that input/output relationships between each student’s proposed systems can be developed. The system needs to relate to or interfere with at least one other existing system, and you need to articulate or show how your system relates to other systems (input and output). Examples of systems include Sol LeWitt's wall drawings, flash mobs, graffiti, stencil art and other urban interventions, generative works or interactive wearables/installations.


In-class, peer-reviewed verbal and or written feedback.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"ebfc347bdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619a4","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"17fc347bdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961979","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Prototyping an Interference System","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":"

Based on peer-evaluation and feedback from the previous class assignment, develop a physical prototype of your interference system. These can be prototyped using whatever medium available (photo, video, PowerPoint, community workshop, installation, performance, wearable circuit, 3D printed, etc.). The prototype can be a mock or paper prototype, but basic interactivity is better than superfluous technical features. Core functionality to demonstrate the intervention is best. The validation of the motivation for the concept is more important than the technical achievement. Use whatever skills and tools you are comfortable with, or experiment with a completely new tool. This prototype will then be deployed in the intended environment or situation. Documentation and discussion on the successes and failures of the system should be kept, as well as any ethnographic study of the users affected. The user can be you, a friend or family member, or to include images, audio, video and text. The contents of this weblog will be presented on the final day of class.


In-class, peer-reviewed verbal and or written feedback.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"77fc347bdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619aa","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"27fc347bdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96198a","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Target an Everyday System","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"20","description":"

This assignment invites you to identify, deconstruct and analyze a system in your everyday life, and develop one or a range of tactics to exploit and interfere with it. Explore the constitutive relations, patterns or processes of this system (e.g. is it social? institutional? Is it technologically maintained? How does it intersect with other systems? Etc.), and develop tactics or processes to interfere with these existing relationships to create new ones. Develop a simple map, narrative or flow diagram of the system and the relationships that you’ve observed and reflected on. Using a series of photos, illustrations or a short video, narrate the observation of system features, their potential points of penetration, and the process in which to exploit theses weaknesses in order to deploy your disruptive tactic. Your documentation should show how this potential interference causes new interconnects in the system, and reflect on how it changed one or more aspect(s) of your everyday life, e.g. What impact did this interfering system have on your life? How did it involve and impact on other people or systems?


In-class, peer-reviewed verbal and or written feedback.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ADAD2402 - Tangible and Embodied Interactions","description":"

This course explores how we can interact with electronic media, through the creation of bespoke physical interfaces and works that go beyond the conventions of the keyboard and mouse - to open up new ways of experiencing, and interacting with digital media, and worlds around and within us. We look at the body as a portal and the interface as prosthesis, amplifier and as transforming mirror.


You will develop your knowledge of working with sensing technologies for controlling audio, visual and/or mechatronic systems, towards the development of an original interactive art or design work, using off-the-shelf components/systems.


Lectures, case-studies and tutorial presentations introduce key precedents and critical issues relating to the conceptualisation and production of interactive artworks, and lab-based workshops and online resources introduce tools and techniques for the creation and presentation of sensor-based interactive artworks.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"453ffcbfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619db","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Body-Focused Interactive Artwork","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

Design and develop an interactive artwork that focuses the participant’s awareness on some aspect of their embodiment, paying special attention to the physicality and materiality of the interface and how these aspects of the work interact with digital processes and electronic media, to frame, amplify and transform their experience of the phenomena explored.

The prototype needs to incorporate some form of analog or digital sensing technology; extract information from the sensor data to control electronic media (e.g. sound, light, images, video, etc) and demonstrate an exploration of physical form, materiality and movement qualities afforded by the object(s) involved – how its form and materiality relates to the body.

The final prototype artwork will be installed and exhibited in a 1-day pop-up exhibition on campus. The work your team exhibits needs to be accompanied by written/visual and/or audiovisual instructions – informing visitors how they can interact with the work to fully appreciate its form and content.

Grading criteria for this assessment are weighted toward the planning and exectution of your project, to encourage iteration and project management within your team (3-4 students).

Please refer to the detailed assessment task brief (available on Moodle in Week 1) for detailed requirements, deliverables and suggested structure.

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"0d3ffcbfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619d4","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"343ffcbfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619b6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"493ffcbfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619d7","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"f43ffcbfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619b3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"fc3ffcbfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619d1","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"203ffcbfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961999","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final Design and Evaluation","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"40","description":"

Document and critically evaluate the interactive artwork you developed and exhibited with your team (Assessment 2), reflecting on the aims you began with, the ways in which the work and concepts evolved (including precedents and ideas/approaches that inspired your team during the conceptualisation, development and/or evaluation of the work), and insights gained through your observation of the ways that people interacted with and responded to the work you exhibited.

From your conclusions, develop a proposed design that explores how this kind of work could be further developed, reflecting on ways that other artists/designers have explored similar technologies or concepts, and how these examples, could inform future iterations of the work you developed with your team. This final design should be documented in video format to serve as a explanatory suport to your in class presentation (5 mins max). This process should also be detailed in a formal report (1000 words).

Please refer to the detailed assessment task brief (available on Moodle in Week 1) for detailed requirements, deliverables and suggested structure.

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"343ffcbfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619b6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"493ffcbfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619d7","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"f43ffcbfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619b3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"fc3ffcbfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619d1","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"783ffcbfdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96199d","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Affordance Experiments: Form, Scale and Materiality","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

This assignment is about working with objects, materials and technologies in a very hands-on way, to explore the idea of interaction affordances: the influence of the physical form, scale, materiality and behaviour of the interface, on what users perceive, do and experience.

For this task you will work individually to design, build and document a collection of experimental prototype objects that can be worn/used by another person, to focus attention on actions and sensations of touch, balance, proprioception and kinaesthesia. This task focuses exclusively on the physical and material aspects of the interface and studio-based exploration of the concept of interaction 'affordances' as described by Don Norman and others.

Document and reflect on your notes from the readings and work done in the studio (1 blog post per week), comprising images/videos with simple point-form notes (max 250 words per post) connecting ideas you have read about and discussed, with what you have done and experienced.

Please refer to the detailed assessment task brief (available on Moodle in Week 1) for detailed requirements, deliverables and suggested structure.

Availability of general education courses outside of the owning Faculty may be restricted by the Program Authority, usually because they are closely related to the study area of the student’s program."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ADAD2610 - Art and Design for Environmental Challenges","description":"

The nature and complexity of 21st century environmental challenges are unprecedented in their urgency and potential consequences for human societies and the natural environment.  Artists and designers have often taken the lead in responding to environmental challenges, and this course provides students in art, design and media art with an understanding of the nature of the global environmental challenge and the ways in which art and design have responded to it.


This course will introduce the major thematics of contemporary environmental science and provide a critical framework for understanding the way artworks, artists, design projects and designers have engaged with and addressed environmental concerns.  You will discuss solo practitioners operating at the local/DIY/ARI level, through to major international artists and designers and the foremost international institutions in this arena. A range of material will be provided to allow you to situate your art and design practice in both local-scale and global-scale contexts.


The course aims to prepare you for the increasingly important roles that ‘environment’ and ‘sustainability’ are playing across all sectors of society, including in art and design. It will equip you with the ability to understand current global trends in environmental sustainability, and techniques and strategies for how art and design can contribute to the response to such challenges. 

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"34cfc1bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619cb","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Human Nature","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"15","description":"

Select 1 object from the 6 you selected for the Nature-culture spectrum activity in Week 2.

Include a photo of your selected object and write a reflection on a hypothetical artwork/design that either uses the object and/or is about the object. Does your hypothetical artwork/design relate to any existing artwork/design? If so, discuss how it relates. What does your hypothetical artwork/design reveal about the nature-culture spectrum?

The purpose of the assignment is to explore what these terms might mean, and apply them to the artefact under investigation.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"38cfc1bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619c7","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"60cfc1bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619bf","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"f8cfc1bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619c4","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"50cfc1bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619a0","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"And Now For Something Completely Different...","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"45","description":"

Part A:

Form a group of 3. Each group will choose a research topic about a 21st century environmental challenge to investigate together. Groups can choose from the course list, or from your own selection. From within your chosen research topic, each person will select one design or artwork about the selected environmental challenge. For example, a group may choose the topic of ‘climate change’ and then each person presents one design or artwork about ‘climate change.’ In this example, you could choose 3 works that are related by medium (e.g. 3 video artworks), or 3 works that each address a different dimension of climate change – 1 on the ecological, 1 on the economic, and 1 on the political.

As a team, you will summarise your individual analyses and prepare a 10 minute visual and verbal presentation on key ideas and arguments of the topic, with each group member describing why the work interests you, and discussing the implications of its engagement with the selected environmental challenge.

The aim is to articulate how the 3 chosen works relate to one another, and how they collectively illuminate the research topic. This allows for each group member to learn from the other members of the group, in terms of each person’s interpretation of the topic and your chosen artist(s) or designer(s). The purpose of this assessment is to increase your vocabulary and understanding of key ideas, themes and terms in current research relating to art and design for environmental challenges.

Part B:

An Individual Submission of a 750-word critical reflection on the artists/designers presented by another group. What merits do you see in the different approach to engaging with the environmental challenges by the artists/designers presented by that group? How does it make you think differently about the approach to environmental challenges that you selected for your presentation? The aim of this critical reflection is to demonstrate how you consider one other approach to environmental challenges, and what, if any, connections you can draw with the initiative that you advocated in your presentation. Part B is due 1 week after Part A is presented.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"accfc1bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619c1","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"f8cfc1bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619c4","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"98cfc1bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619a4","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Art and Design in the Anthropocene","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"40","description":"

For 'Art and Design in the Anthropocene' you will undertake a sustained exploration of an art/design practice that relates to a particular environmental challenge(s). The aim of this assignment is for you to use the insight developed during the course and to reflect on the course content. 

To do so, write an essay that responds to one or more of the following provocations:

1. How does the art/design practice you have selected relate to a particular environmental challenge(s)? Does the practice have any unique qualities in terms of how it relates to an environmental challenge?  

2. Should contemporary art or design engage with the Anthropocene? If so, why and how? If not, why not?

3. What is the role for such artists and designers in contemporary society? Consider such ‘roles’ as ‘avant-guard’, ‘activist’, ‘provocateur’, ‘witness’, ‘agitator’ and debates around art/design representing environmental challenges versus being instrumentalist about the actual challenges.

Critically discuss and expand on one or more of these provocations, drawing on arguments about how specific artists/artworks/designers/designs support your own ideas about ‘Art and Design in the Anthropocene.’

In class you will present a summary of your essay to one other classmate, to take on board any of their feedback as to how your essay presents a case for your vision for art/design in the Anthropocene.

contentlets.keywords: art and design,design,critical practice,critical thinking,critical design,speculative design,sustainabile design,environmental art,bioart,land art,earth art,sustainability,biodiversity,environment,ecology,climate change,anthropocene
contentlets.description:
The nature and complexity of 21st century environmental challenges are unprecedented in their urgency and potential consequences for human societies and the natural environment.  Artists and designers have often taken the lead in responding to environmental challenges, and this course provides students in art, design and media art with an understanding of the nature of the global environmental challenge and the ways in which art and design have responded to it.

This course will introduce the major thematics of contemporary environmental science and provide a critical framework for understanding the way artworks, artists, design projects and designers have engaged with and addressed environmental concerns.  You will discuss solo practitioners operating at the local/DIY/ARI level, through to major international artists and designers and the foremost international institutions in this arena. A range of material will be provided to allow you to situate your art and design practice in both local-scale and global-scale contexts.

The course aims to prepare you for the increasingly important roles that ‘environment’ and ‘sustainability’ are playing across all sectors of society, including in art and design. It will equip you with the ability to understand current global trends in environmental sustainability, and techniques and strategies for how art and design can contribute to the response to such challenges.
contentlets.title: Art and Design for Environmental Challenges

Professional Experience Project is a flexible ‘capstone’ course that provides students in Design, Fine Arts, and Media Arts degrees with an opportunity to synthesise and apply their prior academic learning in a creative workplace. Through this course, you will explore possible career pathways by undertaking professional placement or work experience in a context relevant to your studies and professional interests. Professional experiences require prior approval from the Course Convener. They need to be appropriate in duration as well as have the necessary resources and support from a suitable host.

contentlets.description: Professional Experience Project is a flexible ‘capstone’ course that provides students in Design, Fine Arts, and Media Arts degrees with an opportunity to synthesise and apply their prior academic learning in a creative workplace. Through this course, you will explore possible career pathways by undertaking professional placement or work experience in a context relevant to your studies and professional interests. Professional experiences require prior approval from the Course Convener. They need to be appropriate in duration as well as have the necessary resources and support from a suitable host.
contentlets.title: Professional Experience Project

contentlets.description: Practitioners in the creative industries increasingly articulate the value of their practice in relation to research frameworks. This course explores skills in research methodologies and theories relevant to Art & Design students and provides a suitable foundation for independent investigations and professional practice. The course will introduce you to art and design research methodologies and practice, as well as facilitate the creation of your research direction. You will begin to understand the utility and limits of relevant research frameworks and develop your own approach to them. The aim is to build your confidence in planning, undertaking and evaluating research approaches in order to complete further research oriented study and practice in the future.
contentlets.title: Research Foundations in Art and Design

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ADAD3400 - Interactive Installation","description":"

This studio-based subject explores the transformation of electronic media from a static entity to a dynamic and responsive component of the environment. We will explore how to create rich electronically mediated experiences that operate at a human scale, how interactivity can be utilised to enhance the experience of a work, and how technology can be put into service to create dynamic and responsive environments and objects. You will develop your knowledge of working with sensing and software technologies for controlling audio, visual and/or mechatronic systems and how these can be practically applied in real world circumstances. Through lectures and technical workshops, key precedents, critical issues and practical techniques will be introduced enabling you to conceptualise, prototype and test responsive interfaces and environments.

contentlets.description: This studio-based subject explores the transformation of electronic media from a static entity to a dynamic and responsive component of the environment. We will explore how to create rich electronically mediated experiences that operate at a human scale, how interactivity can be utilised to enhance the experience of a work, and how technology can be put into service to create dynamic and responsive environments and objects. You will develop your knowledge of working with sensing and software technologies for controlling audio, visual and/or mechatronic systems and how these can be practically applied in real world circumstances. Through lectures and technical workshops, key precedents, critical issues and practical techniques will be introduced enabling you to conceptualise, prototype and test responsive interfaces and environments.
contentlets.title: Interactive Installation

honours).","campus":"Paddington","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"ADAD3402","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ADAD3402 - Interactive Generative Visualisations","description":"

Live generative visualisations can commonly be seen at live VJDJ events, often as a set of predefined parameters and as responsive scenography on stage or in museums and galleries.


In this course you will experiment with interactive generative visualisations techniques and examine and deploy powerful low cost computing technologies working with simplified programming methods within a range of potential performative and responsive scenarios.


In this course you will explore the creative possibilities of interactive real-time inputs and will sequentially develop novel strategies through the lens of process philosophies. In conjunction with these aims you will develop your knowledge of generative programming, distributed display and audio techniques and a selection of input and output options to contextualise your concepts.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"d0a6fcf7dbb51c50eb6b147a3a9619f4","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Project Proposal","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

Research and present a proposal (approximately 10 minutes) for an artwork that engages the potential of a responsive generative outcome. Make your case for the proposed form of the work and describe the how interaction will play a role in shaping the audiences experience. The proposal should include: 

• Proposal must indicate your thoughts behind it (concepts).
• Reference other artists or designers as precedence and the works that are relevant to your proposal.  
• Scope of the proposed space, technologies, potential generative characteristics and constraints.- BLACKBOX or IML LAB or other outdoor spaces (consider weather!)
• Overview of production and installation requirements, mockup look and relationships use (Sketchup).
• Speculation on how you think that the audience/participant will engage with the work and your strategies to indicate or afford your hoped for engagement or encounter.

Think of any potentials issues in the interactive system you can foresee, and possible ways to address these issues.

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"5ca6fcf7dbb51c50eb6b147a3a9619ea","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"98a6fcf7dbb51c50eb6b147a3a9619ed","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"4ca6fcf7dbb51c50eb6b147a3a9619cb","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Prototype","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

In this assessment, you will present a proof of concept prototype of a key component that is central to your artwork, for example, a generative and responsive component of the work that maybe part of a larger system. You will demonstrate your prototype to the class for testing and discussion. At this stage, we are not so concerned with the aesthetics of the work; just the mechanics. You will present your experiments throughout the prototype’s development and provide a demonstration of your experimental proof of concept prototype and you will submit documentation online to support your presentation.

The prototype needs to incorporate some form of input technology and generate or produce some form of media, sound, light, images, graphics, text, video etc response and will demonstrate an exploration of generative content production, coded possibilities and potential embodied encoding or interactions to drive the generative process.

You may work in a group (with your tutor’s permission) but your in-class presentation and documentation will need to clearly address your individual contributions as measured by the assessment criteria.

The final artwork will be installed in IML LAB or BLACKBOX.

Your weekly entries (text and images)in your Process Journal will provide essential evidence for your ideas, research, development, and critical engagement processes. 

Your presentation will include:

  • The current state of the prototype and what further development needs to be done to resolve the project.
  • Existing problems and possible solutions.
  • Results from some preliminary tests with real test subjects.
  • What you now need to do to advance to project to completion.

Your additional documentation will include:

  • your project files:
    • Software development (as evidenced by versioned code iterations)
  • one additional document (1000 words) that includes:
    • Project completion timeline, giving the results of the prototype
    • A short descriptive text of the overall process and conceptual contingencies
    • Further refined or adapted sketchup drawings of installation plan proposed

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"98a6fcf7dbb51c50eb6b147a3a9619ed","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"d4a6fcf7dbb51c50eb6b147a3a9619f0","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"84a6fcf7dbb51c50eb6b147a3a9619d0","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Project","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"50","description":"

Set up your work for presentation, documentation and assessment. Your work needs to be ready before presentation to the rest of the class. The spaces will be available before class time for this.

You may work in a group (with your tutor’s permission) but your in-class presentation and documentation will need to clearly address your individual contributions as measured by the assessment criteria.

You will have approximately 15 minutes to give a short demonstration and talk about the work, followed by 5 minutes for other class members to experience the work and ask questions.

Discuss your setup requirements including equipment, lighting and cables etc. with your lecturer beforehand to ensure that you have the equipment and space you need, and that there will be sufficient time to setup the work.

Your additional documentation will include the following:

  • Your weekly entries (text and images)in your Process Journal – these will provide essential evidence for your ideas, research, development, and critical engagement processes leading up to the final presentation.
  • On the day of assessment, you must also document people interacting with your work:
    • Document how they interact with your work - images and/or notes taken during their interaction
    • Note if their interactions confirm or contradict your initial thoughts (from Assessment 1)
    • Include this information in the summative reflection report
  • A summative reflection report (1000 words), due by the end of the week of the presentation, which:
    • will document the interaction of people with the work and whether this confirms or contradicts your predictions – this should communicate something of the human-scale of the work and the experience of being with the work / interacting with the work
    • includes all working code, media and Librariesused to recreate the work
    • if you worked in a group, you also need to clearly outline your individual contributions as measured by the assessment criteria

You will upload this (Code and Media) documentation to Moodle as a zipped folder

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"d4a6fcf7dbb51c50eb6b147a3a9619f0","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"cca6fcf7dbb51c50eb6b147a3a9619d4","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/ADAD3402.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

Please visit WIL website for more information."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ADAD4001 - Professional Experience Project B","description":"

Professional Experience B allows students studying Fine Art, Media Art or Design an opportunity to extend the professional contact time of Professional Experience Project A by an additional 150 hours.


Professional Experience B can be taken to extend a particular work placement and must be taken either contemporaneously or after completing ADAD4000 Professional Experience A.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"6f04a5ffdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961986","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Critical Reflection and Mentor Report","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"50","description":"

This task has a number of documents for submission to be uploaded by the student as one PDF to the PEP Tool as follows:

Part A: PEP Mentor Report and Timesheet

Part B: PEP Critical Self Reflection Report

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"2704a5ffdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961980","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"6304a5ffdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961983","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"ab04a5ffdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a96197a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"e704a5ffdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a96197d","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"1b04a5ffdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a96196b","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Professional Online Profile","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

You are required to complete an Online Professional Profile comprising:

  • Portfolio - at least 5 uploaded images, or a link to your animation, sound work or website, that best represents your practice. This can be created using The Loop or your own website however, all links and profiles should be within one submitted URL.

  • Online CV - The CV clearly sets out for the potential mentor what you have studied, and what relevant experience you have. Key headings for the CV are set out in Moodle and include your current degree program at UNSW Sydney: Art & Design.

  • Artist/Designer statement – approximately 300 words to give some background on your work or your artistic/design/media practice and approach to your professional career.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"2704a5ffdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961980","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"6304a5ffdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961983","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"6f04a5ffdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961977","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"ab04a5ffdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a96197a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"e704a5ffdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a96197d","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"8704a5ffdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961962","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Apply for your Professional Experience","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

There are three ways to arrange a Professional Experience Project placement.  

  1. Arrange your Own placement

  2. Take up an advertised Project Opportunity - Organisations, practices or individual mentors may approach the faculty seeking a PEP student placement, these pre-approved Project Opportunities will be advertised on PEP Tool.

  3. Arrange a Self-Devised Project - If you have an idea that meets the aims of the PEP program outside of the framework above, you will need to upload a completed Application for Self-Devised Professional Placement Proposal for approval.

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"6f04a5ffdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961977","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"ab04a5ffdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a96197a","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"df04a5ffdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961966","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/ADAD4001.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ADAD4010 - Honours Research Project A","description":"

Honours Research Project A requires students in the BFA (Hons), BMA (Hons) and BDes (Hons) to plan and undertake a research project into an issue, topic or area of art and design, and complete studio work along with appropriate documentation.  You will undertake research within themes, which will be developed within particular classes. The themes will allow you to develop a research project which shows the use of appropriate research methods, a high level of scholarship and the ability to plan and execute a project. Support and supervision will be provided within the theme classes.


You may wish to see this course as stage one of a two-part project linked to Honours Research Project B, but this project must be complete in and of itself, and will be assessed independently.


Honours Research Project A contributes 40% of the research project component of your Honours grade.


The submitted work (both written and studio) will be assessed by two independent assessors.

Honours Research Project B requires students in the BFA (Hons), BMA (Hons) and BDes (Hons) to plan and undertake a research project into an issue, topic or area of art and design, and complete both studio work and a written component. You will undertake research within themes, which will be developed within particular classes.  The themes will allow you to develop a research project which shows the use of appropriate research methods, a high level of scholarship and the ability to plan and execute a project. Support and supervision will be provided within the theme classes.


You may wish to see this course as stage two of a two-part project linked to Honours Research Project A, but this project must be complete in and of itself, and will be assessed independently.


Honours Research Project B contributes 60% of the research project component of your Honours grade.


The submitted work (both written and studio) will be assessed by two independent assessors.

contentlets.description:
Honours Research Project B requires students in the BFA (Hons), BMA (Hons) and BDes (Hons) to plan and undertake a research project into an issue, topic or area of art and design, and complete both studio work and a written component. You will undertake research within themes, which will be developed within particular classes.  The themes will allow you to develop a research project which shows the use of appropriate research methods, a high level of scholarship and the ability to plan and execute a project. Support and supervision will be provided within the theme classes.

You may wish to see this course as stage two of a two-part project linked to Honours Research Project A, but this project must be complete in and of itself, and will be assessed independently.

Honours Research Project B contributes 60% of the research project component of your Honours grade.

The submitted work (both written and studio) will be assessed by two independent assessors.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"Paddington","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"ADAD4100","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ADAD4100 - Honours Professional Experience Program","description":"

This course will prepare students to pursue a full-time creative career and develop into versatile artists, designers, thinkers and creative practitioners that work in a constantly shifting design, arts and media arts landscape. Students will investigate creative opportunities that align with their honours major projects and work towards making their aspirational career goals explicit. This course also addresses the challenging aspects of the independent, freelance nature of the creative and cultural industries by providing students with the ability to recognise areas within their creative spheres where they may develop other income streams to support their creative practice.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"ea3bad73dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961995","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Professional Application Preparation","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"5","description":"

Identify two creative or cultural organisations for your professional experience project. Research, write and set out your practice and designer statement that is tailored to your selected organisation. Articulate your professional and creative practice and skills clearly and how you would be the best fit for the project. Submit a tailored CV, a brief designer statement and relevant WIL documents.

Feedback:

Written and verbal feedback will be provided within two weeks from submission

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"2a3bad73dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961989","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"9e3bad73dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961983","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"ea3bad73dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961986","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"463bad73dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961971","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Recognise and explain shifts in Professional Practice","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"5","description":"

Critically evaluate your own applied professional practice and experience during your project and select three skills and attributes that you used in your daily work that underwent a significant shift in your approach and/or interactions with others including an awareness and respect for IP/Copyright protection and ethical practice. Use visual examples with an explanation of where you were at, what changed and where you are at the end of the experience. Submission will be a portfolio online.

Feedback:

Written and verbal feedback will be provided within two weeks from submission

Students, the organisational mentor & internal mentor will complete a final review of the student’s project contributions, professional practice and performance. Students will also identify any gaps for further development and submit an action plan to articulate how they will meet their aspirational professional goals. Submission will be an online survey including an action plan.

Feedback:

Written and verbal feedback will be provided within two weeks from submission

contentlets.keywords: art and design,creative work integrated learning,professional experience,professional practice,creative practitioners,creative ecosystems
contentlets.description: This course will prepare students to pursue a full-time creative career and develop into versatile artists, designers, thinkers and creative practitioners that work in a constantly shifting design, arts and media arts landscape. Students will investigate creative opportunities that align with their honours major projects and work towards making their aspirational career goals explicit. This course also addresses the challenging aspects of the independent, freelance nature of the creative and cultural industries by providing students with the ability to recognise areas within their creative spheres where they may develop other income streams to support their creative practice.

Some research programs involve a coursework component.","campus":"Paddington","study_level_single":{"label":"Research","value":"rsch"},"code":"ADAD9101","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"0 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ADAD9101 - Research Foundations in Art, Design and Media","description":"

This course aims to provide an environment for postgraduate students to develop research foundations necessary for doctoral and/or masters of philosophy candidature, both theoretical and practice-based, in art, design and media arts at UNSW Art & Design . It is designed to assist those who come to postgraduate research without having immediately undertaken extensive written, theoretical or rigorous practice-based training in a prior degree. The course will introduce you to art and design as research, facilitate the refinement of your research proposals, develop understanding of relevant practice-based and literature research fields; understand the use and limits of theoretical frameworks; develop and refine research approach and methods; investigate the thesis as proposition and original contribution and their implications for practice-based research; refine research skills in secondary literature and referencing; and discuss the expectations and approaches to practical components of an art, design or media arts thesis. All meetings will follow a small group discussion format.

How articulate are you as an Artist, Designer, Digital Media practitioner, educator or administrator?


Built on a foundation of English for academic purposes, tailored to specific applications in the creative disciplines, this course will enable you to expand your vocabulary and engage with, interpret and express challenging and complex notions using an appropriate mix of communication strategies best suited to further postgraduate study.

This includes an appreciation of basic research protocols. You will enhance your reading, writing, listening and speaking skills in English to construct coherent intellectual arguments and begin developing your own academic 'voice'. Collaboration in and out of class will use traditional communication approaches and emerging technologies as vehicles for meaningful cross-disciplinary interaction with colleagues, peers, professionals and the public in an articulate and scholarly manner that is informed by your theoretical and practice-based research, critical thinking and self-managed reflective practice.    

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"88cfc1bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a961961","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Interpretive Writing Task","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

This assignment aims to encourage close, critical reading practices and to evaluate your writing skills. In response to the selected reading provided for your degree program specialisation (see Required Readings for Week 1) you are required to:

1. Collaborate in pairs or groups in class tutorials to identify key issues in the set text.

2. Discuss and take notes on the origin, influences and implications of these ideas.

3. Use your notes and answers to individually write your own interpretation of the reading.

4. In 1000 words, using academic English, discuss the importance, meaning, and relevance of this reference.

5. Locate a contemporary art, design or media artwork in the public domain that makes reference to the selected reading provided for your degree program specialisation, (see Required Readings for Week 1. Identify, provide a URL to the image and contextualise the art/design/media artwork. Then write 300 words within the 1000 available for this task analysing how ideas from theory/research have been used in the contemporary artwork. How do the theoretical ideas still speak to this new situation?

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"bbbfc1bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a961952","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"f7bfc1bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a961955","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"abbfc1bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a961933","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Major Essay / Exhibition Review","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":"

In accordance with in-class guidance, you are required to select and produce EITHER:

An exhibition review of a current / existing exhibition, or critical review of a design product, or digital media initiative. Your review must engage with several works in the exhibition (or aesthetic and social aspects of the product / initiative) and discuss the conditions of its presentation and reception

OR

An academic essay relating to an area of interest or investigation. You need to present your question and thesis statement in consultation with your lecturer prior to commencement of writing.

OR

An academic essay presenting a coherent argument in relation to one of the following questions:

1. “Surely the extraordinary success of artificial intelligence is attributable to the fact that it frees us from real intelligence… Surely the success of all these technologies is a result of the way in which they make it impossible even to raise the timeless question of liberty. What a relief! Thanks to the machinery of the virtual, all your problems are over! You are no longer either subject or object, no longer either free or alienated -- and no longer either one or the other: you are the same, and enraptured by the commutations of that sameness.” (Baudrillard, 'Xerox and Infinity')

Discuss the work of two (2) digital media artists who deal with issues such as freedom, social inequality and mass consumption. To what extent do their works challenge the claims that Baudrillard is making above? You should focus on one (1) work by each artist.

2. Discuss the ways in which authenticity, lawlessness and aesthetic spectacle operate in the work of Nan Goldin, Danny Lyon, or Larry Clark. You must analyse three (3) works by your chosen artist in order to support your argument (you may choose to focus on works by two of these artists if you wish, but you must limit the number of works discussed to three).

3. Analyse the sense of 'spirituality' and 'aura' that is so often attributed to the work of Bill Viola. In what does it consist, and why are contemporary audiences so attracted to it? You must analyse two (2) specific works in order to support your argument.

In order to satisfactorily complete this assignment, you must:

• Show proof of research, ideas and evidence beyond that provided in the course readings

• Implement effective essay / review structures

• Integrate and reference academic sources appropriately and effectively

• Compose and write a well-reasoned, presented and referenced academic essay / critical review.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"37bfc1bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a961958","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"bbbfc1bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a961952","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"f7bfc1bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a961955","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"abbfc1bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a961944","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"40","description":"

This task involves preparation and delivery of a 10-15 minute academic presentation to the class, which communicates visual, verbal and written information about an area of interest in the creative arts or your own personal creative practices. This will be followed by a brief group discussion.

Your presentation will include:

1. Engaging and coherent delivery of visual, verbal and written content

2. A speaker-led group discussion at the end based on 2 written questions

3. A one-page hard copy handout of key messages for future reference that includes a clear connection between your chosen area of interest and & current academic conversation/paper/research/creative outputs by artists/designers.

This task requires you to synthesize visual, verbal and written information into a professionally coherent presentation. You may speak in response to mounted material, Prezi or PowerPoint screen, animated segment, Internet page or some other relevant presentation format. The challenge is for you to engage your audience, communicate your message and manage the presentation delivery within the time frame. The aim is to succinctly showcase the meaning and ideas behind your interests or creative works and practices, concluding with a brief group discussion. You will need to be organized, speak clearly and present yourself in a confident, honest and professionally relaxed manner.

Marks for Assignment 3 will be awarded for:

1. Interesting academic, well-paced presentation that engages audience

2. Synthesis of visual, verbal and written information successfully presented in time frame

3. Confident command and delivery of information in chosen format

4. Relaxed personal style in leading group discussion with professional handout provided.
