contentlets.description:
How articulate are you as an Artist, Designer, Digital Media practitioner, educator or administrator?

Built on a foundation of English for academic purposes, tailored to specific applications in the creative disciplines, this course will enable you to expand your vocabulary and engage with, interpret and express challenging and complex notions using an appropriate mix of communication strategies best suited to further postgraduate study.

This includes an appreciation of basic research protocols. You will enhance your reading, writing, listening and speaking skills in English to construct coherent intellectual arguments and begin developing your own academic 'voice'. Collaboration in and out of class will use traditional communication approaches and emerging technologies as vehicles for meaningful cross-disciplinary interaction with colleagues, peers, professionals and the public in an articulate and scholarly manner that is informed by your theoretical and practice-based research, critical thinking and self-managed reflective practice.
contentlets.title: Communication Skills for Creative Disciplines

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Paddington","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"ADAD9114","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ADAD9114 - Research Foundations in Art and Design","description":"

Practitioners in the creative industries increasingly articulate the value of their practice in relation to research frameworks. This course explores skills in research methodologies and theories relevant to Art & Design postgraduate students to provide a suitable foundation for independent investigations and professional practice. The course will introduce you to art and design as research as well as facilitate the creation of your research direction inclusive of both creative theoretical and practice-based approaches. By facilitating an exploration of a range of research fields you will begin to understand the utility and limits of relevant theoretical frameworks and develop your approach to them. The aim is to build your confidence in planning, undertaking and evaluating research approaches in order to complete a major project in the future.  


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"97bf81bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619f9","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Observational Research Report and Presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

Research is methodical searching, to see new things, or existing things in new ways, but in ways that also allow other people to see those things too. A fundamental skill in researching is therefore observing, documenting and analyzing what you have observed. Research quality observing is difficult because we must learn to do what we do every day in new, and more careful ways. You will organise and present prose descriptions of the context, conduct and analysis of your observational research, a field note sample, and a visual essay, comprising a series of annotated and extensively captioned images that communicate clearly new, significant aspects of your observation that emerge from your analysis. This task introduces skills in identifying an issue and applying visualization techniques that can transform everyday looking into researcherly observing.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"03bf81bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619f0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"c3bf81bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619ed","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"3ebf81bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619c1","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Mapping of Precedents and Literature","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

Identifying and organizing information about precedents and literature can seem overwhelming when you begin research. Mapping precedents and literature in a diagram visually communicate relationships between ideas and concepts in projects and publications. Making diagrams of connections and differences between precedents and literature is an important skill because it contextualizes what you have observed with practitioners and researchers who have observed something similar. This task involves searching professional websites and magazines, exhibition catalogues, books and published academic papers, to find projects and publications that relate to your observation in Assessment Task 1.

The visual map diagrams the connections and differences between projects and literature related to your topic using:

·       a minimum of ten precedents for your topic by key practitioners

·       a minimum of ten articles on your topic in professional publications 

·       a minimum of ten scholarly papers and book chapters on your topic by key authors sourced from the UNSW Library Databases of peer-reviewed journals and/or academic publications.

The 300 word synopsis for the visual map outlines: your research area; the issues surveyed; the approach for the groupings; what was discovered; and why the discovery is significant

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"03bf81bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619f0","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"76bf81bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619c6","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Research Project Proposal","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"40","description":"

Research is a validated way of searching for the new: new knowledge; new solutions; new ways of making; new ideas; new ways of communicating new knowledge, solutions, ways of making or ideas. Research is a dialectic between being creative and being careful, between imagining new things through your own observations and analysis of precedents and literature, and checking-in with people about how new and significant what you want to know or make is. The danger of imagining new things yourself is bias; the danger of checking-in is not being able to make your own creative leaps. This final assignment requires you to demonstrate a capacity to manage that dialectic. You must articulate something new that you that you would like to create or come to know. The task is not to do that creative practice research, but rather to do scoping research to validate the need for and significance of what you would like to do or know and how. This will involve you re-performing some of the research techniques you undertook in previous assignments – observational research, practice precedent and literature mapping – and it will involve some new research techniques – preparing questions for a semi-structured interview with a creative practitioner. Synthesizing these together into a clear yet compelling research proposal will require several iterations.

A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Paddington","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"ADAD9211","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ADAD9211 - New Technologies, Traditional Techniques","description":"

This course looks at the ways in which traditional making techniques are transformed by new digital technologies, particularly digital fabrication. It introduces digital fabrication as a method of contemporary making, using case study analysis, exploratory exercises and studio based guidance. The course provides a transitional pathway from analogue to digital methods of object production, and builds on theoretical foundations of machine design and craft to link CAD, 3D modelling and rendering with material forming technologies. You will learn how to use computational design and Computer Numerically Controlled (CNC) technologies such as 3D printing, engraving, laser cutting, routing and engraving to create studio project work in a range of media including ceramics, metal, textile, timber and paper. 


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"e8b17cbbdb751c50eb6b147a3a9619b1","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Online visual journal","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"10","description":"

Research the work of two designers or groups who create tangible works via a ‘hybrid practice’ that incorporates hand and computational fabrication strategies.

Design and illustrate a presentation of a comparative case study on their methodologies, articulating selected aims, conceptual approach, technical processes and a critical discussion of one example of their works. Emphasis should be placed on contemporary practices where innovative and poetic strategies can be clearly identified.

Submit your work as an online visual journal in PDF format. A list of potential designers will be discussed in class to ensure diverse presentations.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"9cb17cbbdb751c50eb6b147a3a96199b","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"44b17cbbdb751c50eb6b147a3a961989","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Studio Studies","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":"

In Studio Studies you will explore and practice a range of skills and knowledge associated with studio tasks that develop different theoretical and empirical aspects of analogue and digital studio practice across the material based studios at the college, namely Ceramics, Plastic, Textiles and Wood.

Whilst gaining studio proficiencies in computational, fabricated and hand crafted modes of design authorship you will need to complete a range of tasks that include conceptual and technical content designed to support your final course project. These tasks include computer drawing and 3D modelling, 3D printing and laser cutting; modelmaking, moulding and casting, folding and joining.

Work should be submitted for a mid term review and final assessment at the course conclusion, accompanied on both occasions by an online visual journal documenting details of practice and progress towards the completion of each task. All studio work should be undertaken in a safe and effective manner, observing appropriate workshop guidelines for processes and equipment that manage the risks of health, safety and environmental impacts.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"90b17cbbdb751c50eb6b147a3a9619ab","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"9cb17cbbdb751c50eb6b147a3a96199b","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"8cb17cbbdb751c50eb6b147a3a96198d","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Hybrid Dialogues: Major Project","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"50","description":"

In this extended project your challenge is to design and exhibit a major work responding to the theme of hybrid interactivity.

Hybridity describes a range of possible conditions that respond to dramatic forces of change emerging in contemporary life, having the potential to disrupt and transfigure traditional binary understandings such as natural/artificial, virtual/material, public/private, autonomous/heteronomous and human/non- human.

Your completed design should be presented alongside an accompanying digital catalogue summarising project work and a journal documenting studio progress. It should evidence the relationship between ideas, process, materiality, interaction and experimental exchange via progressive development and refinement of ideas explored in ‘Hybrid Practices’ research and ‘Studio Studies’ Assessment tasks, with the finished design employing a dialogue between traditional and new craft technologies that explores the notion of interaction in a hybrid system of your choice.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"ecb17cbbdb751c50eb6b147a3a9619ad","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"d4b17cbbdb751c50eb6b147a3a961992","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/ADAD9211.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Paddington","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"ADAD9212","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ADAD9212 - Material Thinking","description":"

This course provides you with a practice-based platform for understanding emerging relationships between materials and creative practice in art and design. Exercises and projects will cover a range of material narratives, exploring the transition from natural to engineered and smart materials; and how this impacts on the design and production of objects, and their aesthetic and functional properties. Theory and discussion will explore perspectives on materialisation embedded in the logic and phenomenology of digital and analogue substance.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"895f34ffdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619b9","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Major Project","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"50","description":"

This Assessment task challenges you to create and present an art or design work that addresses the concept of "social materiality" in the context of a nominated theme, accompanied by a short 'materiality' study and class presentation.

Your project should extend the knowledge of digital and tangible material relationships gained through theoretical and practical course studies and be accompanied by a visual journal that evidences an iterative development of ideas and process, through experimental exploration of different 'materials'.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"055f34ffdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619b0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"415f34ffdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619b3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"8d5f34ffdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619b5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"c55f34ffdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619ad","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"305f34ffdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619a4","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Material Explorations","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"50","description":"

Examine the structural, process, performative and expressive properties of selected materials through a series of practical experimental studies that respond to conceptual design challenges in contemporary making. Present two studies for assessment in class with accompanying documentation and a working visual journal.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"055f34ffdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619b0","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"f45f34ffdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96199f","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/ADAD9212.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Paddington","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"ADAD9311","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ADAD9311 - Designing the Experience: Exhibitions and Beyond","description":"

If you wish to design a wide variety of exhibitions and displays, or work with designers, as a curator, gallerist, or producer, you will benefit from this course. It provides you with the opportunity to address both theoretical and practical aspects of exhibition design and display techniques, as well as the specific design demands of artworks, objects, displays and galleries. You will work with the full range of exhibition design, from project initiation and implementation and design through to final project and audience evaluation.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"6abf81bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a961930","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Exhibition evaluation based on audience experience","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

Summary (See detailed assessment brief on MOODLE): A 1500-2000-word evaluation report of an exhibition of your choosing based on audience experience research. The report should include an analysis of your research and evidence of your data gathering, backed up by an explanation of your research methodology and rationale and design scheme for the techniques used.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"12bf81bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a96192a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"52bf41bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619ff","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"d2bf81bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a961927","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"0ebf41bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619cb","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Collaborative exhibition design project – Group Project","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"50","description":"

Summary (See detailed assessment brief on MOODLE): A collaborative group development of an exhibition design concept for an exhibition brief developed in class time. The concept should include rationale, experiential goals, design schema and visualisations and should cover all the elements of exhibition design. You will summarise your project in a verbal presentation in Week 11 and submit the project paper at the end of Week 11.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"12bf81bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a96192a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"52bf41bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619ff","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"5ebf81bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a96192c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"d2bf81bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a961927","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"8abf41bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619f5","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Analysis of an exhibition design based on a historic or contemporary display paradigm","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

Summary (See detailed assessment brief on MOODLE): 1000-word essay that explores the display strategy of an exhibition of your choice, and shows how it utilizes, invokes or subverts one of the historic or contemporary display paradigms discussed in the topics covered in lectures so far.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"52bf41bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619ff","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"c2bf41bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619c7","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/ADAD9311.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Paddington","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"ADAD9312","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ADAD9312 - Leadership in the Cultural and Creative Industries","description":"

The course provides an understanding of the various definitions of leadership and how they intersect, influence and are shaped by the cultural and creative industries. Leadership is examined from a theoretical and real word perspective to provide you with knowledge and practical techniques to help shape your careers. The idea of leadership takes many forms as distinct from organisational hierarchy, role or status. Cultural leadership is reflected in and by the organisation and industry, and this course demonstrates the interconnectedness of leadership to other disciplines such as marketing, writing, management, creative practice and production. Through lectures, workshops, case studies and action learning you will engage with examples of leadership in cultural and creative organisations, reflect on your own understanding of leadership and develop your own leadership capacity, preparing you for the rapidly evolving cultural landscape.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"0337e5f7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619ff","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Reflective Leadership Essay","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"50","description":"

All students will participate in a variety of action learning activities during classes that will investigate leadership and collaboration from practical perspectives. These interactive activities will put into practice some of the theories that will have been discussed in classes and lectures. In this assessment you are required to write a 2000-2500 word reflective piece on your experience of participating in at least one of the activities and relate it to the leadership theories and issues in the creative and cultural industries. More than one activity may be discussed, and other experiences may be drawn upon from your professional or educational life. The assignment requires that you to do more than describe the experience – you will need to analyse the experience to articulate what you have learned from it, and explain why it is significant. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"0737e5f7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619fb","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"0f37e5f7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619dc","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"4b37e5f7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619df","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"3a37e5f7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619d0","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Leadership Case Study","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"50","description":"

For Part A, in groups of approximately 4, students will prepare a 10-minute presentation demonstrating an example of leadership within the cultural and creative industries. This case study will focus on an individual or a organisation that demonstrates one or more theories and perspectives on leadership. The case study should demonstrate how the organisation or individual engages with leadership practice. This may include analysis of the organisational structure, public material demonstrating leadership approach and role as leaders within the industry.

For Part B, building upon the group work undertaken in Part A, students will each submit an individual report. Utilising and reflecting on the leadership theories discussed in class, readings and through additional research the report should develop and refine the example of cultural and creative leadership in relation to relevant theories and perspectives.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"0f37e5f7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619dc","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"4b37e5f7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619df","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"fe37e5f7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619d9","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"fe37e5f7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619cb","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/ADAD9312.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

Doctorate.","campus":"Paddington","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"ADAD9405","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ADAD9405 - Creative Thinking Processes","description":"

Have you ever had an idea that you wanted to push and develop further, but you weren’t sure how to do it? This course will introduce you to some of the many tools that can facilitate creative thinking. The processes of analysis can help to extend possibilities beyond predictable outcomes, and the same thinking tool can be used across many different disciplines to create new, more integrated and original options and ideas. We will explore visual, verbal and physical ways of transforming ordinary ideas into fantastic ones. Using taught techniques such as the Synectic Pinball Game you will learn to understand more clearly what happens when the creative mind is at work.


We will test the principles of interconnectivity, bisociation (conceptual blending), non-linear (associative) thinking, and use maps, models and metaphors to develop your creative thinking through research, analysis and application of these models to your own ideas. Many famous creative thinkers have used a wide range of processes that we will critically explore and apply.


An important part of understanding and applying the creative process is an examination of how we learn, and how to facilitate the best possible conditions and environments for working in innovative and creative ways. The balance between strategic planning and goal-free approaches to creative processes will be analysed and discussed in relation to the applied research of Professor Teresa Amabile and Professor Tina Seelig amongst others.


Collaborative theory and practice have at their core the potential to extend and enhance outcomes in multi-disciplinary thinking. Relating to this, the model of Combined Divergence will be introduced, and applied to a project-based analysis of the overlaps between critical and creative thinking methodologies.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"3ca778bbdbb51c50eb6b147a3a9619be","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"3. Research Report","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"50","description":"

Assessment Task 3 asks you to consider, the information introduced in the lectures, readings and discussions to date in the course as a whole. These broadly encompass briefs and ideas which can be applied to develop your creative thinking, and they also include different types of processes. The model of thinking applied in Assessment Task 3 is a TRIAD Process first described in Design Synectics by Nicholas Roukes: Refer / Reflect / Reconstruct:

  • Refer to the Lectures, Readings and Discussions, and to research further the links and references within them, selecting areas which interest you.
  • Reflect on the information you select/research and find most interesting in order to relate it to your own personal experiences and/or areas of study. It is important to be able to see how some of the course information and types of creative techniques can be useful to the different careers and kinds of work you will each experience in the future. We tend to remember best what we have a direct experience of, which is why you are asked here not just to think about a creativity technique but to actively apply it in some way.
  • Reconstruct in the form of a summary report what you have learned, discussed and applied to an area of your life eg family, career, study, sport, etc. The Assessment Task 3 Research Report asks you to give at least ONE EXAMPLE of a creativity technique/process selected from the course, being applied as an example to an aspect of your life. In your Reconstruction, reflect on whether or not the technique/process produced the outcome you expected.

Feedback will be delivered to students within 2 weeks of submission of an assessment, and will be uploaded into a private area of the course website. Feedback will consist of a completed assessment rubric indicating the student’s performance against the assessable criteria and a final project grade, and may also include an audio mp3 file containing comments from the lecturer.

The Synectic Pinball Machine","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

The Synectic Pinball Machine is an imaginary model that employs visual, verbal and physical processes to take an idea (the ball) beyond predictable thinking outcomes (through the application of alternative creative pathways). As a Team, select a contemporary issue currently being debated in the newspapers, and process it as a Team exercise in brainstorming through the Synectic Pinball Machine. Collectively summarise in Assessment Task 2 what new and original options, outcomes, solutions and creative ideas this produced in both visual and verbal formats.


Feedback will be delivered to students within 2 weeks of submission of an assessment, and will be uploaded into a private area of the course website. Feedback will consist of a completed assessment rubric indicating the student’s performance against the assessable criteria and a final project grade, and may also include an audio mp3 file containing comments from the lecturer.

A New Idea","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

By researching and exploring a key creative person, we can become more informed about: what traits made someone creative; what environments existed to make certain periods have high creativity (and conversely, what environments or conditions held certain individuals back); what processes of creative thinking a key creative person used, and finally, how these three things (traits, environment, processes) integrated together to make the life of that individual notable for her/his creative achievements.

We will also continue to discuss the differences and similarities between creativity, innovation and critical thinking - many well known key creative people in history have shown outstanding abilities in all three of these areas. In this illustrated 2000 word Assessment Task 1 you are asked to choose one key creative historical person to research. Discuss their contributions in relation to their traits, environment and processes. You may choose someone from any discipline area, but they should not be alive - this allows you to discuss their complete life and creative contribution. Please structure your illustrated essay/discussion paper using these four sub-headings in the following suggested order:

  • Context - Environment and upbringing/personal history/introduction?
  • Concept - Ideas your chosen person had and why (creativity)?
  • Content - How they went about making their ideas a reality (processes)?
  • Constraints - How they overcame difficulties, and problem-solved (thinking).

Feedback will be delivered to students within 2 weeks of submission of an assessment, and will be uploaded into a private area of the course website. Feedback will consist of a completed assessment rubric indicating the student’s performance against the assessable criteria and a final project grade, and may also include an audio mp3 file containing comments from the lecturer.

This course is designed to help you experience the full potential of your own creativity by engaging in experimental art, design or digital media practices. You will also learn how to apply these principles of experimentation to your own area of study in this intensive course.


This course will extend your knowledge, research and technical skills through discourse and engagement in reflective practice and concept development. You will work with peers from a wide range of backgrounds such as design, science, medicine, creative artists, engineering, architecture, mathematics, etc., to develop practice-led research within the areas of emerging technologies. You will be guided in generating random data based upon a physical location, which you will visualise in different creative mediums. The result of this process will be a body of work through which you can demonstrate your experimental process, resulting in a range of innovative, unexpected creative outputs. By engaging with this process using a range of emergent technologies, you will broaden your existing knowledge and skills, and develop a framework for experimentation that is current, innovative, personally meaningful, and professionally relevant.

Students initiate physical experiments and collect documentary evidence of random processes used to identify and generate data on a physical location. Students are assessed on the presentation of their experiments in the form of a portfolio.

\n

 


Feedback will be given in class and by written feedback
